data.title: Can I Change My Mind After Requesting an Absentee Ballot?
data.meta_description: I requested an absentee ballot. Can I change my mind and vote at the polls? The answer varies by state. Use our chart to determine what works best for you.
data.text:
I requested an absentee ballot. Can I change my mind and vote at the polls? Here are your state-specific rules.

With all the chatter about different ways of voting, many people are wondering about their options. We are receiving a lot of inquiries from voters about whether someone can change their mind and go to the polls if they have already requested an absentee ballot. Unfortunately, there is no single answer - it varies by state. This chart will help you determine what works best for you.

If you do change your mind and decide to go to the polls, in most cases, you’ll be asked to sign a sworn statement attesting that you have not already voted. You cannot go to the polls to change your vote, if you already cast your ballot. (Those are two very different things, friends;-) Voting more than once is against the law.

In all cases, we recommend sticking to your original voting plan - if you requested and received an absentee ballot, it is best to vote that ballot. Changing your mind creates additional work for poll workers and election officials in a year when there is already significant pressure on our election system.

We've identified 5 situations you may encounter, depending on your state: *see below for further detail on the definitions of these 5 situations

Note: These provisions apply to voters who have already requested an absentee ballot. If you have not requested an absentee ballot, check our Elections Dates and Deadlines page to find out when you can vote in-person and vote early.

State (1) Regular ballot without surrendering absentee ballot (2) Regular ballot if you surrender absentee ballot; provisional ballot if you do not (3) Provisional ballot for all absentee requests (4) You can only vote-by-mail (5) Notes and Other Circumstances Alabama ✔ Alaska ✔ Arizona ✔ Arkansas ✔ California ✔ Colorado ✔ Connecticut ✔ Delaware ✔ District of Columbia ✔ Florida ✔ Poll workers will confirm that you have not already voted with an absentee ballot Georgia ✔ Take your absentee ballot with you to the poll to be cancelled. You must RETURN your cancelled ballot in order to vote. Hawaii ✔ You can return your ballot, or vote, in person Idaho ✔ Illinois ✔ Indiana ✔ Iowa ✔ Kansas ✔ Kentucky ✔ You must vote absentee, unless you have not received your ballot by Oct. 28th

You can vote in person without surrendering your absentee ballot, and the absentee ballot will be canceled Louisiana ✔ Maine ✔ Maryland ✔ Massachusetts ✔ Michigan ✔ Minnesota ✔ Mississippi ✔ Missouri ✔ You may vote in person by contacting your local election official to make an appointment Montana ✔ 46 of 56 counties are vote by mail only You may drop off your ballot rather than mail it, the location is provided in your voter materials, or you can contact your election administrator for a location Nebraska ✔ Nevada ✔ ✔ New Hampshire ✔ New Jersey ✔ New Mexico ✔ New York ✔

If you have been issued an absentee ballot, you can only vote in person by using a provisional ballot

North Carolina ✔ North Dakota ✔ Ohio ✔ Oklahoma ✔ Oregon ✔ You can vote in person at your county's election office Pennsylvania ✔ Rhode Island ✔ South Carolina ✔ South Dakota ✔ Tennessee ✔ Texas ✔ Utah ✔ ✔ Vermont ✔ ✔ ✔ Virginia ✔ Washington ✔ ✔ You may go to a voting center if you want to vote in person West Virginia ✔ Wisconsin ✔ You can take your absentee ballot with you to vote absentee in person at your clerk's office, or take your absentee ballot with you to a voting location on Election Day Wyoming ✔
